I have written many search warrants, and I have never yet written one for a residence that searches just for the illegal contraband (the drugs, the illegal guns, the stolen property, etc.). Social security cards, birth certificates, the cable bill, phone bills, tax documents, etc. are all frequent targets of residential search warrants. These documents are not illegal contraband per se but they can be evidence of a link to criminal activity. For example, if you are searching a drug house these documents can help show who stays there, rents the house, or pays the bills-which in turn can provide evidence of that person's possible link to the criminal activity at the house. A search for a specific cell phone is an indication that evidence exists to show the cell phone has been used to promote criminal activity (to set up drug deals, for example). Asking about any guns present is a common safety precaution. In addition to making sure no one looses their temper and tries to use one, there have been occasions where guns which have been hidden were accidentally fired by officers conducting a search. It is also possible the officers were attempting to elicit an incriminating statement if the presence of a gun at the house would have been unlawful (if certain drugs were already in the house, or if the person were a felon, for example). 
 
 As far as tearing up the house goes, it is a matter of individual officer discretion. Search warrants authorizing a search for a particular item justify searching anywhere within the house that the item could possibly be hidden. I teach search warrant writing and I preach that the warrant should be written to include the smallest possible item your probable cause will support. Say, for example, you stumble across a filing cabinet in a house you are searching. If all you have listed to look for in the search warrant is the stolen 52in plasma TV then you cannot open the drawers and look inside (unless you are prepared to later explain to the judge how you thought it possible to find a TV inside the drawer) But if you are looking for drugs (or ammunition, shell casings, etc)-well they can be hidden anywhere-and a search warrant would authorize you to even open up the walls if the officers felt it necessary to do so.
 
 Regardless of what you are looking for, though, every item listed on a search warrant must be supported by probable cause to believe that the item you want to seize is not only evidence relevant to prove criminal activity but is also believed to be at the residence you are going to search. If the item is not listed in the search warrant, then officers who stumble onto it during a search for other items may not seize it unless it is "immediately apparent" that the item they have stumbled on is evidence of a crime (for example, you open a closet door looking for the stolen TV listed in the search warrant and instead find several marijuana plants and a grow light).
